marienplatz.name: Marienplatz
marienplatz.description: Munich's historic central square - the city itself was founded here in 1158. Home to the famous Glockenspiel that performs daily at 11am and 12pm (plus 5pm in summer). This is where locals meet, tourists gather, and Munich's history comes alive.

transit: All tram and bus lines pass through nearby
transportation.walking: Central location - walkable from anywhere in Altstadt

venues.name: Neues Rathaus (New Town Hall)
venues.description: Gothic revival building with the famous Glockenspiel. Shows at 11am, 12pm, and 5pm (March-October). Free to watch!

venues.name: Ratskeller
venues.description: Historic underground restaurant in the town hall basement. Traditional Bavarian food since 1874.

venues.name: Kaufingerstra√üe
venues.description: Main shopping street starting from Marienplatz. Mix of international brands and local shops.

venues.name: Frauenkirche
venues.description: Munich's iconic cathedral with twin onion domes. Climb the tower for city views (7.50 EUR).

visitInfo.bestTime: Come 10 minutes before Glockenspiel shows (11am/12pm/5pm). Weekday mornings are less crowded. Avoid during Bayern Munich victories - it gets packed!
events: Christkindlmarkt (Christmas Market) - Late November to December 24th, one of Germany's oldest
tips: The Glockenspiel tells two stories: a 1568 royal wedding and the Schaefflertanz (coopers' dance)
Climb the Peterskirche tower nearby for the best view of Marienplatz (5 EUR, 300 steps)
Free public restrooms in the Rathaus basement (follow signs)
Don't eat at the square - it's tourist-priced. Walk 5 min to Viktualienmarkt for better food
Stand to the north side for best Glockenspiel viewing (less crowded, better angle)

englischer_garten.name: Englischer Garten

venues.name: Monopteros Temple
venues.description: Hilltop Greek temple with panoramic city views - perfect sunset spot and people-watching

venues.name: Paddle Boat Rental

Christmas market at Chinesischer Turm (late November-December)
Concerts at Chinesischer Turm beer garden (summer weekends)
tips: Buy cheap beer from supermarkets (Edeka, Rewe) and drink it in the park - totally legal and saves ‚Ç¨6-8 per beer!
Don't be shocked by nude sunbathers - it's normal German culture (FKK zones)

Bring your own food to beer gardens and just buy drinks - allowed at all Munich beer gardens

tips: Book Olympic Stadium roof climb in advance - super popular! ‚Ç¨35-45 per person

Each room has different Japanese-inspired decor

Rotating exhibitions + guided bike tours to Munich street art hotspots.

Exhibitions change regularly - check website for current shows
Photography allowed in most areas
Combine with exploring nearby G√§rtnerplatzviertel neighborhood

tips: Arrive early (before 9am) for best selection!
Bring cash - most vendors don't accept cards
Bargaining is expected and part of the fun
Wear comfortable shoes - lots of walking
Perfect for vintage fashion, vinyl records, and unique souvenirs

rathaus_wurmeck.name: Wurmeck Dragon (Town Hall)
rathaus_wurmeck.description: See the dragon that 'brought the plague' to Munich! At the western corner (Wurmeck) of the Neues Rathaus, a dragon statue stares down ominously. Legend says a wingless dragon flew over Munich during the plague outbreaks (17th century) bringing plague with poisonous breath. Brave men killed it with a cannon shot at this very spot.

transportation.walking: Western corner of the Neues Rathaus at Marienplatz

tips: Look for the Wurmeck corner - west side of the Rathaus
Dragon statue watches over the pedestrians below
Great photo opportunity!
Combine with Marienplatz Glockenspiel visit
The Black Death killed over 7,000 Munich citizens
visitInfo.legend: During the 17th-century plague, locals believed a huge wingless dragon brought death with its poisonous breath. After brave men killed it with a cannon, the city commemorated the legend with this statue.

venues.name: Wurmeck Dragon Statue
venues.description: Historic dragon sculpture on town hall tower. Legend says it protects Munich. Look up!

venues.name: Photo Spot
venues.description: Not many tourists know about the dragon! Hidden gem for photos.

venues.name: Town Hall Tours
venues.description: Guided tours include dragon history. Learn Munich legends and folklore.

marienplatz_1.question: What year was Munich founded?
marienplatz_1.explanation: Munich was founded in 1158 by Henry the Lion near what is now Marienplatz, making this the historic heart of the city for over 860 years!
marienplatz_1.funFact: The square was originally called 'Schrannen' (grain market) and was renamed Marienplatz in 1854 to honor the Virgin Mary.

marienplatz_2.question: How many times per day does the Glockenspiel perform?
marienplatz_2.explanation: The Glockenspiel performs three times daily: at 11am, 12pm, and during summer also at 5pm.
marienplatz_2.funFact: The Glockenspiel has 43 bells and 32 life-sized figures performing two historical stories!

marienplatz_3.question: Best time to visit Marienplatz without crowds?
marienplatz_3.explanation: Early morning (before 9am) or late evening (after 8pm) offer the most peaceful experience!
marienplatz_3.funFact: Locals rarely watch the Glockenspiel - it's mainly a tourist attraction!

englischer_1.question: How does Englischer Garten compare to Central Park?
englischer_1.explanation: At 3.75 km¬≤, Englischer Garten is larger than New York's Central Park (3.41 km¬≤)!
englischer_1.funFact: The park extends 5.5 km from city center to Munich's northeastern border!

englischer_2.question: What unique sport happens at Eisbach?
englischer_2.explanation: The Eisbach has a standing wave perfect for river surfing year-round!
englischer_2.funFact: Surfing here was illegal until 2010, but locals did it anyway for decades!

englischer_3.question: Which beer garden is NOT in Englischer Garten?
englischer_3.explanation: Augustiner-Keller is in Neuhausen, not the Englischer Garten!
englischer_3.funFact: Chinesischer Turm beer garden seats 7,000 people - Munich's second-largest!

englischer_4.question: Why is it called the 'English' Garden?
englischer_4.explanation: It's designed in the English landscape garden style - natural, not formal like French gardens!
englischer_4.funFact: It was created in 1789, making it older than both Central Park and Hyde Park!

olympiapark_1.question: Which Olympics were held here?
olympiapark_1.explanation: The 1972 Summer Olympics were held in Munich, showcasing revolutionary architecture!
olympiapark_1.funFact: The stadium also hosted the 1974 FIFA World Cup Final!

olympiapark_2.question: What was here before Olympiapark?
olympiapark_2.explanation: It was military training grounds covered in WWII rubble. 3 million m¬≥ of rubble created the artificial hills!
olympiapark_2.funFact: The transformation from destruction to Olympic glory symbolized Munich's rebirth!

olympiapark_3.question: What's special about the stadium's roof?
olympiapark_3.explanation: The acrylic glass canopy suspended by steel cables was revolutionary in 1972!
olympiapark_3.funFact: Inspired by spider webs, it became a model for future stadium architecture worldwide!

olympiapark_4.question: What's a fun activity at Olympiapark?
olympiapark_4.explanation: You can actually climb the Olympic Stadium roof on a guided tour - amazing views!
olympiapark_4.funFact: The Olympic Tower (291m) has a revolving restaurant at the top!

frauenkirche_1.question: When was Frauenkirche completed?
frauenkirche_1.explanation: Construction finished in 1488! The iconic onion domes were added in 1525.
frauenkirche_1.funFact: The towers are slightly different heights: North tower is 98.57m, South is 98.45m!

frauenkirche_2.question: What's the 'Devil's Footprint' (Teufelstritt)?
frauenkirche_2.explanation: A black footprint in the entrance floor! Legend says the devil left it after being tricked by the architect.
frauenkirche_2.funFact: Stand on the footprint - no windows are visible from that spot due to clever pillar placement!

frauenkirche_3.question: Why can no building in Munich's center be taller than Frauenkirche?
frauenkirche_3.explanation: Munich law prohibits central buildings taller than 99m (Frauenkirche height) to preserve the skyline!
frauenkirche_3.funFact: This height limit keeps the historic skyline intact and makes Munich instantly recognizable!

frauenkirche_4.question: Which movie featured Frauenkirche prominently?
frauenkirche_4.explanation: Quentin Tarantino's Inglourious Basterds (2009) featured the church in several scenes!
frauenkirche_4.funFact: Many WWII films use Munich as a shooting location due to its preserved historic architecture!

hofbraeuhaus_1.question: When was Hofbr√§uhaus founded?
hofbraeuhaus_1.explanation: Founded in 1589 by Duke Wilhelm V of Bavaria as the royal brewery!
hofbraeuhaus_1.funFact: 'Hofbr√§u' means 'court brewery' - it was originally exclusively for the royal court!

hofbraeuhaus_2.question: How much beer does a Ma√ü (mass) contain?
hofbraeuhaus_2.explanation: A Ma√ü is exactly 1 liter! It's the traditional Bavarian beer serving size.
hofbraeuhaus_2.funFact: The Hofbr√§uhaus serves about 10,000 hectoliters of beer annually - that's 1 million liters!

hofbraeuhaus_3.question: What historic event happened here in 1920?
hofbraeuhaus_3.explanation: Hitler held an early Nazi party meeting here in 1920. The hall has dark history.
hofbraeuhaus_3.funFact: Famous visitors include Mozart, Lenin, and John F. Kennedy!

hofbraeuhaus_4.question: What should you NOT do at Hofbr√§uhaus?
hofbraeuhaus_4.explanation: Never sit at tables marked 'Stammtisch' - these are reserved for regulars who have their own beer steins stored there!
hofbraeuhaus_4.funFact: Over 2,000 regulars have personalized steins stored in locked cabinets!

viktualienmarkt_1.question: When did Viktualienmarkt open?
viktualienmarkt_1.explanation: The market opened in 1807 when Marienplatz became too crowded for farmers!
viktualienmarkt_1.funFact: 'Viktualien' is an old word for food/victuals in German!

viktualienmarkt_2.question: What's special about the beer garden here?
viktualienmarkt_2.explanation: The beer garden rotates through Munich's six major breweries weekly - try them all!
viktualienmarkt_2.funFact: It's one of the few beer gardens in Munich's city center!

viktualienmarkt_3.question: What do the statues around the market represent?
viktualienmarkt_3.explanation: The fountains feature famous Munich comedians and actors from Bavarian folk theater!
viktualienmarkt_3.funFact: Karl Valentin, Liesl Karlstadt, and Weiss Ferdl are among those honored!

residenz_1.question: How many rooms does the Residenz have?
residenz_1.explanation: The Residenz has 130 rooms open to the public - one of Europe's largest palace museums!
residenz_1.funFact: It was the seat of Bavarian rulers for over 400 years (1508-1918)!

residenz_2.question: Which architectural styles are combined in the Residenz?
residenz_2.explanation: Built over 400+ years, it combines Renaissance, Baroque, Rococo, and Neoclassical styles!
residenz_2.funFact: Each section reflects the taste of the ruler who built it, creating a time capsule of architecture!

residenz_3.question: What treasure can you see in the Schatzkammer (Treasury)?
residenz_3.explanation: The Treasury houses Bavarian crown jewels, including crowns, scepters, and regalia dating back centuries!
residenz_3.funFact: The collection includes a ruby from the 11th century and King Ludwig II's ceremonial sword!

allianz_1.question: Which teams play at Allianz Arena?
allianz_1.explanation: Only FC Bayern M√ºnchen plays here now. TSV 1860 left in 2017.
allianz_1.funFact: The stadium can hold 75,000 fans and sells out almost every match!

allianz_2.question: Why does the stadium glow different colors?
allianz_2.explanation: The facade has 2,874 illuminated inflatable ETFE panels that can glow red, blue, or white!
allianz_2.funFact: It glows red for Bayern, blue for Germany national team, and rainbow for Pride events!

allianz_3.question: How many Champions League titles has Bayern won at Allianz Arena?
allianz_3.explanation: Surprisingly, Bayern has never won a Champions League final at home! Their wins came at neutral venues.
allianz_3.funFact: They won the 2013 and 2020 Champions League titles but not at Allianz Arena!

allianz_4.question: Which U-Bahn line goes directly to Allianz Arena?
allianz_4.explanation: Take U6 to Fr√∂ttmaning station - it has a direct walkway connection to the stadium!
allianz_4.funFact: On match days, trains run every few minutes and it's the easiest way to reach the arena!

deutsches_museum_1.question: What's unique about Deutsches Museum?
deutsches_museum_1.explanation: It's the world's largest science and technology museum with 28,000+ exhibited objects!
deutsches_museum_1.funFact: You'd need about 8 days to see everything if you spent 1 minute per exhibit!

deutsches_museum_2.question: When was Deutsches Museum founded?
deutsches_museum_2.explanation: Founded in 1903 by engineer Oskar von Miller to make science accessible to everyone!
deutsches_museum_2.funFact: The museum survived WWII bombings, though 80% of the building was damaged!

deutsches_museum_3.question: What's a must-see exhibit?
deutsches_museum_3.explanation: The high-voltage demonstrations with massive lightning bolts are legendary!
deutsches_museum_3.funFact: They also have original aircraft, submarines, and the first automobile ever built!

nymphenburg_1.question: Who was born at Nymphenburg Palace?
nymphenburg_1.explanation: King Ludwig II, the 'fairy tale king,' was born here in 1845!
nymphenburg_1.funFact: Ludwig II later built Neuschwanstein Castle (Disney's inspiration)!

nymphenburg_2.question: What style is Nymphenburg Palace?
nymphenburg_2.explanation: Nymphenburg is a magnificent example of Baroque architecture started in 1664!
nymphenburg_2.funFact: The palace grounds span 200 hectares - perfect for a leisurely stroll!

nymphenburg_3.question: Why was Nymphenburg Palace originally built?
options: As a summer residence and hunting lodge for the Bavarian royals
As a museum from the start
nymphenburg_3.explanation: Nymphenburg was built starting in 1664 as a summer residence for the Bavarian electors. It was later expanded into the magnificent Baroque palace complex we see today!
nymphenburg_3.funFact: The name 'Nymphenburg' means 'Castle of the Nymphs' - inspired by the mythological water nymphs said to inhabit the palace gardens!

nymphenburg_4.question: What unique feature can you find in the palace's park pavilions?
options: The Amalienburg hunting lodge with its Hall of Mirrors - a rococo masterpiece
nymphenburg_4.explanation: The Amalienburg is a stunning rococo hunting lodge in the palace gardens, famous for its breathtaking Hall of Mirrors covered in silver and blue decorations!
nymphenburg_4.funFact: The Hall of Mirrors in the Amalienburg is considered one of the finest examples of rococo architecture in Europe - even more intimate and beautiful than Versailles!

bmw_welt_1.question: When did BMW Welt open?
bmw_welt_1.explanation: BMW Welt opened in 2007 with its stunning futuristic architecture!
bmw_welt_1.funFact: It's one of Munich's most visited attractions with 3+ million visitors annually!

bmw_welt_2.question: Is entry to BMW Welt free?
bmw_welt_2.explanation: Yes! BMW Welt is completely free to enter and explore!
bmw_welt_2.funFact: You can see the latest BMW models and watch new car deliveries happening live!

bmw_welt_3.question: What else is nearby BMW Welt?
bmw_welt_3.explanation: BMW Welt is right next to Olympic Park - perfect for a combined visit!
bmw_welt_3.funFact: The BMW Museum next door has over 120 cars spanning BMW's history!

glockenbach_1.question: What's Glockenbach known for?
glockenbach_1.explanation: Glockenbach is Munich's hippest neighborhood with trendy bars, cafes, and vibrant nightlife!
glockenbach_1.funFact: It's also the center of Munich's LGBTQ+ scene!

glockenbach_2.question: What street is Glockenbach's main bar strip?
glockenbach_2.explanation: Hans-Sachs-Stra√üe and surrounding streets are packed with cool bars and restaurants!
glockenbach_2.funFact: The area used to be working-class but gentrified into Munich's trendiest quarter!

glockenbach_3.question: Best day to experience Glockenbach nightlife?
glockenbach_3.explanation: Friday and Saturday nights are when Glockenbach really comes alive!
glockenbach_3.funFact: Many bars stay open until 3am or later on weekends!

hauptbahnhof_1.question: How many platforms does Munich Hauptbahnhof have in total?
hauptbahnhof_1.explanation: M√ºnchen Hauptbahnhof has 34 platforms in total, making it one of Europe's largest railway stations!
hauptbahnhof_1.funFact: It serves over 450,000 passengers daily - that's more people than many German cities!

hauptbahnhof_2.question: When was the current station building opened?
hauptbahnhof_2.explanation: The current station opened in 1909, replacing an older 1849 station!
hauptbahnhof_2.funFact: The famous arched roof was revolutionary for its time!

hauptbahnhof_3.question: What's the cheapest way from Hauptbahnhof to the airport?
hauptbahnhof_3.explanation: S1 and S8 trains go directly to the airport in about 40 minutes for just ‚Ç¨11.60 with the Airport-City Day Ticket!
hauptbahnhof_3.funFact: Trains run every 10 minutes and you can use it for unlimited MVV travel all day!

isar_1.question: Can you swim in the Isar?
isar_1.explanation: Yes! Many sections are popular for swimming in summer. The water is cold but refreshing!
isar_1.funFact: The Isar flows from the Austrian Alps through Munich to the Danube!

isar_2.question: What do locals do at the Isar in summer?
isar_2.explanation: The Isar banks are THE place for BBQs, sunbathing, and socializing in summer!
isar_2.funFact: It's basically Munich's beach - bring a portable grill and enjoy!

isar_3.question: What unique feature does the Isar have?
isar_3.explanation: The Isar was 'renaturalized' - cement removed so it flows naturally with gravel banks!
isar_3.funFact: This ‚Ç¨40 million project (2000-2011) created Munich's urban wilderness!

schwabing_1.question: What was Schwabing famous for in the early 1900s?
schwabing_1.explanation: Schwabing was Munich's bohemian quarter, home to artists like Kandinsky and writers like Thomas Mann!
schwabing_1.funFact: Lenin lived in Schwabing for several years before the Russian Revolution!

schwabing_2.question: Which art movement was born in Schwabing?
schwabing_2.explanation: Der Blaue Reiter (The Blue Rider), a key expressionist group, was founded here by Kandinsky and Marc!
schwabing_2.funFact: The movement revolutionized modern art and influenced expressionism worldwide!

schwabing_3.question: What's the main street in Schwabing?
schwabing_3.explanation: Leopoldstra√üe ('Leo') is Schwabing's boulevard with cafes, shops, and student life!
schwabing_3.funFact: The street comes alive during summer with outdoor seating everywhere!

sendlinger_1.question: How many medieval gates does Munich still have?
sendlinger_1.explanation: Three gates remain: Sendlinger Tor, Karlstor, and Isartor from Munich's medieval walls!
sendlinger_1.funFact: The city walls were torn down in 1791 to allow Munich to expand!

sendlinger_2.question: What's near Sendlinger Tor?
sendlinger_2.explanation: Sendlinger Stra√üe is one of Munich's best shopping streets with lots of stores!
sendlinger_2.funFact: It's a mix of international chains and local boutiques!

sendlinger_3.question: When was Sendlinger Tor originally built?
sendlinger_3.explanation: Sendlinger Tor was built in 1318 as part of Munich's medieval fortification system!
sendlinger_3.funFact: The gate survived when the city walls were demolished in 1791 - it's over 700 years old!

muffathalle_1.question: What was Muffathalle originally used for?
muffathalle_1.explanation: Muffathalle was a historic power station transformed into Munich's coolest cultural venue!
muffathalle_1.funFact: The industrial architecture makes for an incredible concert atmosphere!

muffathalle_2.question: What happens at Muffathalle?
muffathalle_2.explanation: Muffathalle hosts everything from indie rock to electronic music to cultural events!
muffathalle_2.funFact: International acts and local heroes all play here - check their calendar!

muffathalle_3.question: What's special about Muffatwerk (connected venue)?
muffathalle_3.explanation: Muffatwerk is a cafe/cultural space connected to Muffathalle - perfect for pre-concert drinks!
muffathalle_3.funFact: It's also a coworking space during the day with great coffee!

muffathalle_4.question: Where is Muffathalle located?
muffathalle_4.explanation: It's right by the Isar river in the hip Haidhausen neighborhood!
muffathalle_4.funFact: Perfect location - you can chill by the river before/after concerts!

flaucher_1.question: What's Flaucher famous for?
flaucher_1.explanation: Flaucher is THE place for riverside BBQs, swimming, and hanging out in summer!
flaucher_1.funFact: Locals bring portable grills and party here all summer long!

flaucher_2.question: When is the best time to visit Flaucher?
flaucher_2.explanation: Sunny summer days and warm evenings are when Flaucher comes alive!
flaucher_2.funFact: Grab beer, food, and friends - it's Munich's ultimate outdoor party!

flaucher_3.question: Can you swim at Flaucher?
flaucher_3.explanation: Swimming in the Isar at Flaucher is super popular! The water is cold but refreshing!
flaucher_3.funFact: Be careful - the current can be strong. Stay in shallow areas!

flaucher_4.question: What's the unique beer garden rule at Flaucher?
options: You can bring your own food, just buy drinks
flaucher_4.explanation: The Flaucher beer garden follows traditional Bavarian beer garden rules - bring your own food and just buy the drinks!
flaucher_4.funFact: This is a classic Munich tradition - locals pack picnics and enjoy affordable beer under chestnut trees!

flaucher_5.question: What's NOT allowed on Flaucher's gravel beaches?
flaucher_5.explanation: Glass bottles are banned on the beaches for safety - park rangers actively enforce this rule!
flaucher_5.funFact: Bring cans or plastic bottles instead. The rule protects bare feet from broken glass on the gravel!

p1_1.question: Why is P1 so exclusive?
p1_1.explanation: P1 has a famously strict door policy - dress well and be prepared to wait!
p1_1.funFact: It's Munich's celebrity hotspot - FC Bayern players party here!

p1_2.question: What building is P1 located under?
p1_2.explanation: P1 is in the basement of the Haus der Kunst art museum!
p1_2.funFact: The contrast between high art upstairs and nightclub below is iconic!

p1_3.question: Since when has P1 been THE celebrity club?
p1_3.explanation: P1 has been Munich's most exclusive club since the 1990s!
p1_3.funFact: If you get in, you're officially cool (or lucky)!

augustiner_1.question: What makes Augustiner-Keller special?
augustiner_1.explanation: Locals swear by Augustiner-Keller as Munich's most authentic beer garden!
augustiner_1.funFact: 5,000 seats under chestnut trees - it's massive and magical!

augustiner_2.question: Can you bring your own food to Augustiner-Keller?
augustiner_2.explanation: Traditional Bavarian beer gardens allow you to bring your own food! Just buy the beer!
augustiner_2.funFact: Grab pretzels and cheese from nearby shops and enjoy under the trees!

augustiner_3.question: Which brewery supplies Augustiner-Keller?
augustiner_3.explanation: Augustiner beer - Munich's oldest brewery and locals' favorite!
augustiner_3.funFact: Many M√ºnchners consider Augustiner the best Munich beer!

augustiner_4.question: When should you arrive to get a table?
augustiner_4.explanation: On nice weather weekends, arrive before 6pm or you'll struggle to find seats!
augustiner_4.funFact: But half the fun is wandering around looking for space!

filmstadt_1.question: What famous movie was filmed here?
filmstadt_1.explanation: The NeverEnding Story (Die Unendliche Geschichte) was filmed at Bavaria Filmstadt!
